content.body: Since the page I used for an example is a work in progress, I decided that I would discuss here what I am doing with it. It is supposed to be as complete a list as possible of every tag and attribute that has existed in the history of HTML and the W3. I am finding that with the previous versions of the DTD (the SGML based ones through 4.01) it is easy to determine what attributes were given to each element. In the Living Standard version, being removed from the SGML requirement for things to be so specific, the specification is written very differently. It has become difficult to determine exactly which attributes should be listed with a given element, and which attributes from the past are no longer relevant. I am also having difficulty with finding a list of the onEvent attributes (such as onMouseDown) in the HTML 5 specification. Is there a concise list?

content.body: It also seems like the Global Attributes contain members that are not all useful on every element that has them. Is there a way to differentiate between them as they pertain to a given element?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It also seems like the Global Attributes contain members that are not all useful on every element that has them. Is there a way to differentiate between them as they pertain to a given element?

content.body: Also, I feel I should make a distinction in what I said in my first post. I am not saying Firefox is right and everyone else is wrong. I'm saying that there needs to be an agreed upon definition of proper rendering that all browsers should adhere to if they want to render web pages correctly. Then all web pages would look the same in every browser no matter what platform or browser the user has. Of course, there are limits, such as different screen size and resolutions. The authors of the web pages would have to ensure that they code the pages in such a way that it accommodates as many users as possible, realizing that there will be some users who simply won't see the page as intended.

The authors of the web pages would have to ensure that they code the pages in such a way that it accommodates as many users as possible, realizing that there will be some users who simply won't see the page as intended.

content.body: wayneca: FWIW, although we do define how HTML maps to CSS in the Rendering section of the HTML Standard, how those CSS rules translate into a picture on your screen is not something the WHATWG works on (W3C's CSS WG does), though many here have some expertise in it. (And some a lot.)
content.formatted_body: wayneca: FWIW, although we do define how HTML maps to CSS in the Rendering section of the HTML Standard, how those CSS rules translate into a picture on your screen is not something the WHATWG works on (W3C's CSS WG does), though many here have some expertise in it. (And some a lot.)

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> wayneca: FWIW, although we do define how HTML maps to CSS in the Rendering section of the HTML Standard, how those CSS rules translate into a picture on your screen is not something the WHATWG works on (W3C's CSS WG does), though many here have some expertise in it. (And some a lot.)

Thanks for your input. I realize that the focus of the WHATWG may not be the same as the W3C, but this is the only forum I know of that has so many browser developers in one place. I am reaching out to the browser developers because this is something that has not really been addressed in the history of the W3 that I know of.

content.body: All three major browser vendors are members of W3C. How exactly a page is rendered (how flex works, how tables should flow, etc) is all specified by the CSSWG. You can see the members here: https://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/members.en.php3
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: All three major browser vendors are members of W3C. How exactly a page is rendered (how flex works, how tables should flow, etc) is all specified by the CSSWG. You can see the members here: https://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/members.en.php3

content.body: Also, if it was all so straight-forward as the specification defines it, different browsers would not render the pages so differently. I believe that this can and should be remedied by the browser developers coming together and defining the specifics of what a rendered page should look like.

content.body:
> <@wayneca:matrix.org> Also, if it was all so straight-forward as the specification defines it, different browsers would not render the pages so differently. I believe that this can and should be remedied by the browser developers coming together and defining the specifics of what a rendered page should look like.

The problem here is not specifications. They exist. The problem is that there are three different engines with different bugs. If you see rendering differences, then these are bugs in individual engines.

content.body: I don't know about how things are rendered on your system, but in mine the differences between Firefox and Chrome are because I don't have Tahoma installed in my system, and different browsers use different fallback fonts. So that's also something that you can't expect browsers to agree on.
I see. So it's a matter of finding and squashing the bugs.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I see. So it's a matter of finding and squashing the bugs.

content.body:
> <@wayneca:matrix.org> I see. So it's a matter of finding and squashing the bugs.

We have shared test suites to tackle this, but they do not have 100% coverage. And even with 100% perfect coverage, the actual implementation of the specs definitly follows the 80:20 rule. The last 20% of issues is just as hard as the first 80%.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @wayneca:matrix.org
I see. So it's a matter of finding and squashing the bugs.

content.body: I have already specified sans-serif as a family in my font-family property. Is that not enough for a system to use whatever is available on a system that doesn't have Tahoma?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I have already specified sans-serif as a family in my font-family property. Is that not enough for a system to use whatever is available on a system that doesn't have Tahoma?

content.body: That is enough, and the text will render in whatever font the browser chooses.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That is enough, and the text will render in whatever font the browser chooses.

content.body: That is what I thought too, but I updated the files to include  Verdana, Arial, Helvetica also.

content.body: That’s usually not necessary (unless you really have a preference for those fonts). Picking your first desired font, then having a generic family fallback is fine
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That’s usually not necessary (unless you really have a preference for those fonts). Picking your first desired font, then having a generic family fallback is fine

content.body: OK. I had thought that was the case, but when Andreu Botella stated that they didn't have Tahoma installed on their computer it made me rethink.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: OK. I had thought that was the case, but when Andreu Botella stated that they didn't have Tahoma installed on their computer it made me rethink.

content.body: Tahoma, Verdana, Arial, Helvetica are all fonts that come with Windows systems and don't tend to come with, say, Linux
there are fonts with the same metrics that might come in Linux systems, but they don't have those names
That is why I initially included sans-serif in the family list: font-family:Tahoma, sans-serif;
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That is why I initially included sans-serif in the family list: font-family:Tahoma, sans-serif;

content.body: I thought I understood that this would allow a system that didn't have Tahoma to fall back on whatever sans-serif font it has.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I thought I understood that this would allow a system that didn't have Tahoma to fall back on whatever sans-serif font it has.

content.body: if there are multiple, browsers are free to choose one, and different browsers might choose differently
Well, I really don't have the means to see what every sans-serif font looks like, so I try to allow the user to determine their own preference when possible.

content.body: Hi, I hope this is a good place for my question. I tried to figure out why only link and script tags support SRI. I had a chat with Eric Lawrence, and he told me that there are some theoretical plans to support it (see https://www.w3.org/TR/SRI/#verification-of-html-document-subresources). Does anyone know what the current status of this is? Eric told me that potentially Mike West might have some insights, but maybe also someone else knows anything about it.
content.formatted_body: Hi, I hope this is a good place for my question. I tried to figure out why only link and script tags support SRI. I had a chat with Eric Lawrence, and he told me that there are some theoretical plans to support it (see https://www.w3.org/TR/SRI/#verification-of-html-document-subresources). Does anyone know what the current status of this is? Eric told me that potentially Mike West might have some insights, but maybe also someone else knows anything about it.
